Tracking/discussion issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/504 - HIP https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0074-mobile-poc-modeled-coverage-rewards.md
valerie 11/29/2022 8:58 PM
HIP 74: MOBILE PoC - Modeled Coverage Rewards Author(s): @thehardbits , @zer0tweets , @jpad-freedomfi, @meowshka Start Date: 2022-11-29 Category: Technical & Economic Original HIP PR: HIP: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/503 Tracking Issue: HIP 74: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/504 Summary This HIP proposes the first Proof-of-Coverage reward scheme for the MOBILE network and the method it will use to govern rewards in the current Genesis Phase, and beyond. This coverage scheme, known as Modeled Coverage, attempts to predict the coverage that a MOBILE radio provides to a surrounding area using radio characteristics, location data provided during the CBRS CPI registration process, and a public topographical database. This calculation will be performed by a new entity known as an Obstruction Data Oracle, which is an automated process that can predict how a signal will propagate into the surrounding area. This scheme replaces the current Genesis Phase scheme that relies solely on self-reported Hotspot parameters such as Radio Heartbeats and network Speed Tests. While these items are hard to spoof, they are not verified by external sources and provide limited information about the quality of coverage that a Radio provides. Modeled Coverage improves upon the current scheme by taking into account the directionality of Radios and environmental obstructions that prevent the propagation of the signals they generate. Once implemented, Modeled Coverage will be a significant milestone in introducing the Proof-of-Coverage concept in the Mobile Network. It's covered in a detailed MOBILE PoC roadmap in the blog post MOBILE Proof-of-Coverage: The Road Ahead MOBILE Proof-of-Coverage: The Road Ahead as Obstruction Data. Combined with other parameters like uptime (Heartbeats) and backhaul (Speed Test), it allows for more fair rewards and incentivizes the deployment of Radios at optimal locations. Rendered View: https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0074-mobile-poc-modeled-coverage-rewards.md (edited)
HIP: MOBILE PoC via Modeled Coverage by ke6jjj · Pull Request #503 ...

waveform 11/30/2022 10:06 AM
Note Summary of the call today, call playback will be available here later https://www.helium.foundation/community-call First of a series of HIPs aimed at rewarding 5G hotspots for actual coverage Initial was online status and physical pictures. Then was online status then backhaul tests. Next â€¦ does your radio provide any useful coverage at all? This is NOT a replacement for SPOT mappers, but a step in that direction. It will be a while before mapper devices are out there in great numbers. We know the physical information and the direction/height/power of the radio With location and clutter data (obstructions like trees buildings) we can predict coverage. We get this â€œclutter dataâ€ from a clutter data oracle. We can then calculate what rewards these hotposts should receive. This is modeled coverage, next is blended with mappers and then mapped coverage. This affects only 5G+CBRS radio hotspot installations, not IOT hotspots. Your MOBILE rewards could increase if your coverage is calculated to be good, less if coverage is bad or there is duplicate coverage. The hex you are in will change in size to a Resolution 12 sized hex (IOT uses Resolution 8 sizes), and the coverage will be displayed in Res 12 sized hexes. What the radio really covers. Two kinds of Radios, Outdoor, for each hex that provides coverage you will earn different levels of â€œreward pointsâ€ in three levels. Indoor, we don't easily know the clutter data for indoor radios. We assume that the deployment hex is high level, and the adjacent hexes are low level. MOBILE rewards will be based on the sum of the reward points in the coverage. For Multiple Radios that cover the same Hex, the 5 have that have the strongest signal, only those get rewarded. We will launch a MOBILE explorer application so you can see rewards you would receive under this HIP before we this HIP is made live for rewards. Q: What about duplicating existing Mobile operators coverage or providing unused coverage? A: More HIPs to adjust rewards based on usefulness of coverage are planned Q: Will some Hexes will rewarded more than others? A; HIP74 rewards for providing coverage of any strength.There will be different MOBILE rewards for strength of coverage in Hexes in future HIPs. Q: What is the confidence in the Radio height data? A: We validate to the best of our ability, but SPOT mappers will be able to validate this. Asserted wrong heights are an FCC violation, and can incur a fine. (edited)
waveform pinned a message to this channel. 11/30/2022 10:07 AM
gutentag 11/30/2022 10:10 AM
For anyone trying to visualize sizes of the different hex resolutions: https://h3geo.org/docs/core-library/restable/#average-area-in-m2 A res 12 hex is a smidge larger than a tennis court A res 8 hex is about the size of Disney Land (edited)
Tables of Cell Statistics Across Resolutions | H3
Cell counts

valerie 11/30/2022 10:56 AM
reposting answer from @jpad jpad: Another question someone posted in the question link I want to answer here too: Q: If you have two CBRS outdoor radios (430) pointed opposite each other how does the scoring/HIP handle this? Example is two 430s back to back pointed 270 and 90 degrees. A: this is totally valid deployment strategy. This would result in each radio covering a unique set of res 12 hexes, so rewards for each radio would be unaffected by the other radio.

I assume all eight would get any and all data traffic rewards. (edited)

meowshka 11/30/2022 12:43 PM

KeithR
Is it five to a hex because that is tacit acknowledgement that you need five 430Hs to provide 360-degrees of coverage?
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 12:46 PM
up to 5 radios will get POC rewards for overlapping coverage in a single hex. why 5? because beyond 5 the coverage is not accretive, but destructive since CBRS doesn't have enough unique channels for SAS separate more than 5 radios, radiating into the same hex
1

I assume all eight would get any and all data traffic rewards. (edited)

zer0tweets 11/30/2022 2:53 PM
no, tiers 1-4 will kick in right away. these tiers are for signal strength but any hex at any location with strong signal will be worth 16 points... regardless of it being in downtown New York or middle of Lake Michigan. Later HIPs will deal with notion of usefulness, so eventually not all hexes with strong signal will be the same
zer0tweets
no, tiers 1-4 will kick in right away. these tiers are for signal strength but any hex at any location with strong signal will be worth 16 points... regardless of it being in downtown New York or middle of Lake Michigan. Later HIPs will deal with notion of usefulness, so eventually not all hexes with strong signal will be the same
waveform 11/30/2022 2:56 PM
So first stage is how many hexes you cover and their signal strength and later its how useful that coverage is?

Brainstormer 11/30/2022 3:01 PM
this is a h12 hex. say i have access to the whole building rooftop, for every hex, im allowed to put 5 radios covering 360 there will be overlap (edited)
15:01
how will that affect my rewards if the coverage overlaps with radios pointing at eachother
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 3:03 PM
each hex can have max 5 radios projecting signal into it that will be rewarded
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 3:04 PM
15:04
i count 25 hex that i can put 5 in each for a total of 125 radios and won't affect reward. is that right?
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 3:04 PM
no... you have to get away from the Lora notion of "radio living inside a hex"
15:05
we don't care so much about which hex the radio is located in... we only care which hexes the radio radiates into
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 3:05 PM
talking about 2 different things, one is how many allowed inside a hex (5). coverage, will all be overlapped if i actually put 5 radios in each hex. (edited)
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 3:06 PM
there is no limit on how many radios allowed in a hex (edited)
15:06
you can put 100 in the same hex, if they have 1 degree sector antennas pointing in 100 directions they will all get rewarded
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 3:07 PM
i think i get what you mean. if 6 radios all point at the same area only the first 5 will get rewarded.
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 3:07 PM
yes, you got it
15:08
...and rewards will be calculated based on hexes they cover, not the hex that they are physically located in
waveform pinned a message to this channel. 11/30/2022 3:10 PM
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 3:10 PM
so if i put them all on the same building rooftop, best would be to point them all facing outwards to reduce overlap, although there will be some, but no more than 5
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 3:11 PM
yes, exactly
15:11
and you can put them all next to each other pointing in different direction too, you won't earn much less for it vs. spreading them out into different corners
15:12
all we care about is the actual coverage the radio creates and how it conflicts with coverage other radios create, not where the radios are located on the roof

KeithR 11/30/2022 4:04 PM

16:05

16:06

Brainstormer 11/30/2022 4:06 PM
if you have 6 radios all pointing in the same direction. only 5 of those with strongest signal would get paid. (edited)
KeithR 11/30/2022 4:07 PM
With indoor, it doesn't matter which way they are pointing according this model. You get points for the one you are in and points for the surrounding hexes; no? So put five indoors in the center hex, and all six hexes are also max'd out. [really all seven of the hexes would get max'd out] (edited)
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 4:09 PM
that's how i got the 40 points. my question is if there are limits on how many radios
KeithR
With indoor, it doesn't matter which way they are pointing according this model. You get points for the one you are in and points for the surrounding hexes; no? So put five indoors in the center hex, and all six hexes are also max'd out. [really all seven of the hexes would get max'd out] (edited)
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 4:11 PM
yes, that's correct.
16:12
there is not limit on how many radios per hex indoor, but, indirectly, because of how coverage is calculated, if you put more than 5 indoor radios into the same hex, you won't get any more rewards
16:13
...because you'll saturate the hex you are in with 5 radios "radiating" strong signal into that hex
zer0tweets
...because you'll saturate the hex you are in with 5 radios "radiating" strong signal into that hex
KeithR 11/30/2022 4:16 PM
So in the picture above I could, not that I would but I could, put 5 indoors in each of the 7 hexes and get rewarded for all 35 of them?
KeithR

except your GPS would probably say they're all in the same hex lol unless there happens to be a window in each hex
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 4:19 PM
not exactly... each indoor radio will cover 7 hexes. 1 with strong signal and 6 with weak signal. each hex will reward at most 5 radios with top signal. if you shove 5 radios into each hex, you will oversaturate most of the neighboring hexes. so you will get rewarded, but it will get scaled down
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 4:21 PM
5 in each hex , you'd get 5 strong in each hex and lose the all the weak ones except for the most outer hexes adjacent to the strong
Brainstormer
5 in each hex , you'd get 5 strong in each hex and lose the all the weak ones except for the most outer hexes adjacent to the strong
zer0tweets 11/30/2022 4:22 PM
yes
16:23
if you have better suggestions on a template to model coverage for indoor, it's definitely an area for improvement

KeithR 11/30/2022 5:07 PM
Assuming one indoor radio in each hex... Seems to me that the center hex would get 16 for the one in there and 4 x 8 from four of the green ring around it. The green ring around the center would get 16 for each radio in it plus 3 x 4 from the center radio and the two in front and behind in the ring.. The purple ring would get 2 x 4 from the two radios adjacent from the green ring. So these seven radios would earn you 48 (center) + 168 (green ring) + 96 (purple ring) = 312 units. Meanwhile one outdoor on the roof gets 900+ units. Not so good for indoor radios with PoC. But indoors will win in the end from the data traffic (80% makes a difference).
KeithR
Assuming one indoor radio in each hex... Seems to me that the center hex would get 16 for the one in there and 4 x 8 from four of the green ring around it. The green ring around the center would get 16 for each radio in it plus 3 x 4 from the center radio and the two in front and behind in the ring.. The purple ring would get 2 x 4 from the two radios adjacent from the green ring. So these seven radios would earn you 48 (center) + 168 (green ring) + 96 (purple ring) = 312 units. Meanwhile one outdoor on the roof gets 900+ units. Not so good for indoor radios with PoC. But indoors will win in the end from the data traffic (80% makes a difference).
Brainstormer 11/30/2022 5:17 PM
you're competing a fixed max 40 points to outdoor radios that can still be improved once explorer comes out, so as outdoor radios adjust for better coverage, the % indoor radio earns will get less and less.

zer0tweets
if you have better suggestions on a template to model coverage for indoor, it's definitely an area for improvement
Chris 11/30/2022 5:38 PM
Coming up with a great solution for indoor PoC is wicked hard. I don't have anything wonderful to offer, but I'd strongly consider making the rewards for multiple indoor radios diminish sharply when multiple radios are in the same hex. Under the current rules, I think we'd see lots of places where there are stacks of 5 indoors in the exact same place. I'd maybe adjust it so that if there's multiple indoors making it into the top 5, they get scaled down aggressively. E.g., 2 indoors and they're eligible for 1 + 1/2 indoors worth of coverage (60 pts)...5 indoors and they're eligible for 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/4 + 1/5 indoors worth of coverage (91 pts) This proposal would suck for the skyscraper with 20 genuinely useful radios, but realistically, 95%+ of duplicate radios won't be contributing much on the margin if the system in the HIP is implemented (edited)
Chris
Coming up with a great solution for indoor PoC is wicked hard. I don't have anything wonderful to offer, but I'd strongly consider making the rewards for multiple indoor radios diminish sharply when multiple radios are in the same hex. Under the current rules, I think we'd see lots of places where there are stacks of 5 indoors in the exact same place. I'd maybe adjust it so that if there's multiple indoors making it into the top 5, they get scaled down aggressively. E.g., 2 indoors and they're eligible for 1 + 1/2 indoors worth of coverage (60 pts)...5 indoors and they're eligible for 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/4 + 1/5 indoors worth of coverage (91 pts) This proposal would suck for the skyscraper with 20 genuinely useful radios, but realistically, 95%+ of duplicate radios won't be contributing much on the margin if the system in the HIP is implemented (edited)
KeithR 11/30/2022 5:42 PM
I have a commercial four story building. Concrete floors, crappy coverage through most of the center of the building. I will need at least two per floor as there is an actual firewall in the middle of the building; so one on each side facing towards each of the two ends. I might even need four per floor; one on each end facing inwards or a radio half way down also pointing out (on each side of the firewall). So at least 8 radios. Maybe 16, though I really hope not. Your idea is not so good for this scenario; and I have at least 5 of these types of building that I have the opportunity to do. And they ain't that special of a building either. (edited)
17:44
That ten story apartment in Kansas (the Netherlands Apartments) doesn't need 280 radios for sure but given the design of the building I could see it needing 4 maybe 5 per floor. that would be at least 40 radios.

i'm ready to concede that my idea would be causing something negative in your situation. Important for us to be realistic here though and recognize that the perfect is the enemy of the good. For every situation like yours, there will be dozens of people putting five radios next to eachother on a shelf

KeithR 11/30/2022 5:49 PM
I just don't understand why outdoor radios are being so overly rewarded. We know that 80% of traffic will be via indoor radios. We know that we are supposed to be covering where large groups of very slow moving people are gathering. There just aren't that many people walking down the street streaming Netflix. But waiting at the doctor's office...yes sir.

17:56
And we haven't even begun to discuss what "useful" coverage will be in the future. Seattle already has pretty damn good cell coverage. So this round of PoC rewards are going to make me put the radios up on the roof of some four and five story buildings to which I have access. But then four months from now a new HIP will say "oh this doesn't work any more because there is already plenty of cell coverage in this area". Once again, Nova has pushed me to the edge; they do this every time with their first drafts.

Chris 11/30/2022 6:05 PM
Couple of other pieces of feedback on the HIP while I've got it on my mind: -4 points for Tier 3 (poorly covered) hexes seems awfully high to me. I'd consider dropping that to 1 point. Under the HIP's proposed system, I think weird stuff gets encouraged...e.g., putting a small cell super high with a non-aggressive angle--covering lots of hexes but not covering any of them well. Would also consider just dropping Tier 3 to 0 points. Would simplify things. Any outdoor cell covering some hexes excellently will also cover some hexes poorly. Idk that it needs to be rewarded directly. -Not familiar with how the modeling works, but 105-130dBm on a UE seems pretty lousy. If not implementing something like I suggested above, I might consider altering Tier 3 so its more like 100-110dBm -It might be worth tying rewards to population density in this HIP (even if its a pretty basic implementation). Otherwise, putting small cells high up on farms looks awfully rewarding. Could just piggyback on Kontur's data for population in res8 hexes -- https://data.humdata.org/dataset/kontur-population-dataset (take the population in the res8 parent hex & multiply it by res12-hex-area /res8-hex-area to get a rough estimate of population density)
2
1

Couple of other pieces of feedback on the HIP while I've got it on my mind: -4 points for Tier 3 (poorly covered) hexes seems awfully high to me. I'd consider dropping that to 1 point. Under the HIP's proposed system, I think weird stuff gets encouraged...e.g., putting a small cell super high with a non-aggressive angle--covering lots of hexes but not covering any of them well. Would also consider just dropping Tier 3 to 0 points. Would simplify things. Any outdoor cell covering some hexes excellently will also cover some hexes poorly. Idk that it needs to be rewarded directly. -Not familiar with how the modeling works, but 105-130dBm on a UE seems pretty lousy. Chris 11/30/2022 9:12 PM
To be clear, that "-" is a bullet point not a negative symbol. Under the HIP, hexes with -105 to -130dBm are worth 4 points (that's 1/4 of the points an excellently covered hex is worth). I'm suggesting dropping that to either 1 or 0 points

dropping tier 3 would benefit indoor radios.

KeithR 12/01/2022 12:55 AM
You just need to put the GPS pucks on all sides of the building. That way you can have maybe 10 hexes covered; now you are at 50 radios. If they have obstruction data that is clean enough to base a rewards system on, then the system also knows you are inside a 28-story building. So "additional proof" would seem unnecessary. The object data that Google uses is friggin amazing. The system knows enough that they can guesstimate which floor each radio is on by its GPS and elevation data. Again, it shouldn't be hard.

Anthonyra 12/01/2022 5:07 AM
Yea not sure why theyâ€™re multiples of 4 seems like extra math or â€œfluffy numbersâ€ for no reason.
Anthonyra 12/01/2022 5:24 AM
I also donâ€™t like the per radio approach since like Chris said above it incentivizes people to install high power setups over very flat land (farms) vs in places that need the coverage. I think that a better approach would be how well does a group of radios provide coverage for the res 11 or even 10. Give each area rewards that can be divided up by shares based on the individual radios. For example, a perfect res10 would have 49 res12s that each hotspot provides â€œperfectâ€ signal strength. This would be the max possible. Each res11/10 would have a noise multiplier based on the obstruction data. The more noise the harder it would be to achieve the perfect hex so the rewards would reflect that. Remove the first come first serve (just because theyâ€™re first doesnâ€™t mean they are actually providing the best coverage or good coverage) or just keep first come first served when data isnâ€™t being metered resulting in the majority of the rewards. All the radios in the parent hex are calculated normally. Then you determine all â€œperfectâ€ res12s in that parent. This is the score for the parent. The parent is rewarded based on its ratio to a â€œperfectâ€ parent. The hotspots inside split the share based on how many of the tier 1s it provided. No need for the rest of the tiers. You could also combine tier 1 and 2 into an â€œperfectâ€ signal strength range to make it easier to achieve an ideal res11/10 (edited)

AndrewsMD 12/01/2022 5:44 AM

HimanshuTyagi 12/01/2022 5:48 AM
Great. Congrats Nova labs and Boris. We have designed an open and decentralized proof of backhaul which can be used for decentralized backhaul speed test. Here is a draft of the paper: https://witnesschain.com/assets/pdf/Proof_of_Backhaul.pdf This can facilitate open and community-driven backhaul verification. It will be great if we can work with Nova labs to do a PoC with Mobile subDAO. We do have a working prototype with WiFi.

Great. Congrats Nova labs and Boris. We have designed an open and decentralized proof of backhaul which can be used for decentralized backhaul speed test. Here is a draft of the paper: https://witnesschain.com/assets/pdf/Proof_of_Backhaul.pdf This can facilitate open and community-driven backhaul verification. It will be great if we can work with Nova labs to do a PoC with Mobile subDAO. We do have a working prototype with WiFi.
Anthonyra 12/01/2022 5:52 AM
I read this a while ago and itâ€™s does appear to be way better than client side speed tests for sure. But unless you guys develop an integrations or sidecar docker image for the gateways itâ€™ll probably not come to fruition
HimanshuTyagi 12/01/2022 5:58 AM
Yes! Thatâ€™s what we want to figure out. How to integrate it. We do have a Magma integration and demo. But to move forward for integration with Helium, we need to work with someone from Nova labs. Who would be the right person?
06:00
The paper gives the high level protocol, but there are a lot of details about the implementation and the communication middleware. Our current implementation is based on MQTT for comm since it had a light client for OpenWRT and we wanted to make the protocol work with WiFi as well
Anthonyra 12/01/2022 6:00 AM
I mean itâ€™s almost all open source.. if you get the code together and a HIP itâ€™ll probably end up being a quick vote

-My suggestion to account for population density would probably be a huge benefit for indoor nodes in good locations -you make a good point that, under this system, people probably wonâ€™t buy lots of indoor radios to game with. Still, I donâ€™t like the idea of not encouraging people to distribute radios that are currently stacked together. -Iâ€™ve already acknowledged there are legitimate reasons someone might put 5+ indoor radios in one hex. Sounds like you have a situation like that. But letâ€™s please please not pretend thatâ€™s the typical scenario. In the vast majority of cases where several radios are in the same spot, the extra radios are not providing meaningful value -Iâ€™d be in favor of reducing the number of radios eligible for rewards in each hex (or scaling down rewards as radios become redundant). 5 radios seems excessive at this stage. Concurrent users constraints arenâ€™t important in the short-term -A well-placed 430i is pretty clearly worth 20x+ an indoor node with a shitty placement. With PoC and coverage modeling, Helium has mechanisms to determine whether a 430i is well-placed. Helium doesnâ€™t have equivalent mechanisms to figure out whether an indoor radio is well placed (edited)

Very valid points. People installing on mountains or open flat land, areas that may provide little-to-no actual data providing, will end up earning a lot more than those installed at locations with little multi-hex coverage but infinitely more actual data usage providing.

Anthonyra 12/01/2022 6:53 AM
The population idea is sound, with exception of the fact John brings up. How do we get that data and then it's another data set we need to "trust" we are already needing to trust an obstructions data set. My suggested approach assumes the obstructions in the already used data set is "mostly" buildings. If so we can use that as a proxy to "population". (edited)
Chris
-My suggestion to account for population density would probably be a huge benefit for indoor nodes in good locations -you make a good point that, under this system, people probably wonâ€™t buy lots of indoor radios to game with. Still, I donâ€™t like the idea of not encouraging people to distribute radios that are currently stacked together. -Iâ€™ve already acknowledged there are legitimate reasons someone might put 5+ indoor radios in one hex. Sounds like you have a situation like that. But letâ€™s please please not pretend thatâ€™s the typical scenario. In the vast majority of cases where several radios are in the same spot, the extra radios are not providing meaningful value -Iâ€™d be in favor of reducing the number of radios eligible for rewards in each hex (or scaling down rewards as radios become redundant). 5 radios seems excessive at this stage. Concurrent users constraints arenâ€™t important in the short-term -A well-placed 430i is pretty clearly worth 20x+ an indoor node with a shitty placement. With PoC and coverage modeling, Helium has mechanisms to determine whether a 430i is well-placed. Helium doesnâ€™t have equivalent mechanisms to figure out whether an indoor radio is well placed (edited)
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 12/01/2022 6:57 AM
Does population density cover it tho, your targeting people in transit there, eg london (London, London) has 0 population basically but during work hours is packed with people
Anthonyra 12/01/2022 7:20 AM
Also isn't the main goal simply is this "area" coverage and my suggestion above would without a doubt ensure that's the case
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io
Does population density cover it tho, your targeting people in transit there, eg london (London, London) has 0 population basically but during work hours is packed with people
Chris 12/01/2022 7:56 AM
It's imperfect. Similar story for thing like sports stadiums...no one lives there but a lot of people go there. I wouldn't want population density to be the end-all-be-all of rewards. And in the long run, it'd be good to do some kind of smoothing. E.g., maybe you don't just look at the population in a given hex, but also place moderate weight on the population within 1km, a bit of weight on the population within 10km. One thing I'd note--what I suggested earlier (guesstimating a res12 hex's population from a res8 population estimate) does implicitly do a bit of "smoothing" automatically. And the res8 population estimates themselves probably involve some smoothing--I expect those are roughly estimated based on census tract boundaries that don't neatly line up with hexes (edited)
Anthonyra 12/01/2022 7:57 AM
Uhh this HIP... MIP is missing sections no? Drawbacks, Rationale and Alternatives, Unresolved Questions, Deployment Impact, and Success Metrics?? Does nobody appreciate HIP7 anymore

My suggested approach assumes the obstructions in the already used data set is "mostly" buildings. If so we can use that as a proxy to "population". (edited)

Chris 12/01/2022 9:16 AM

Anthonyra 12/01/2022 9:18 AM
It actually brings up a good point about how the rewards will be cycled through? Because you need to reward overlap to get the total Coverage points of an "area". Since the simplified example has this area be only 4 hexes but no where does it describe how this "area" will be determined. I'm thinking that all radios submits tx power to ODO (obstruction data oracle) which produces the hexes that's covered and tier based on the calculated dBm. This builds out all the res12 coverage hexes. It could then back out to a bigger hex (res11/10 maybe even res8) which could be called reward hexes. Each of the reward hexes would have rewarded hotspots. Hotspots could be in multiple reward hexes. It would also allow a noise multiplier to be implemented to allow for reward capping of an area and increased rewards for increased difficulties. (edited)
1

Chris 12/01/2022 9:51 PM
Yeah, I think the line between usable and unusable is blurry. My feeling is that what we should really incentivize is good coverage. With the way RF works, anyone providing good coverage in some places will, highly likely, be providing lousy coverage in other places. If gives meaningful incentives for lousy coverage, I think weâ€™ll get weird behavior from small cell hosts. A 430i can send a detectable but profoundly shitty signal pretty far
HimanshuTyagi
Actually, this requires a simple integration with the FreedomFi AGW. Without any discussion with Nova labs, we can put down our best guess integration proposal (which is what we have implemented with Magma). But will be good to discuss this.
Anthonyra 12/02/2022 2:14 AM
Unfortunately the AGW isnâ€™t open sourced yet atleast to my knowledge. However, if that was done on the AGW side then you wouldnâ€™t provide that service for the IOT or even the future WiFi side of things. Which is why a sidecar might make sense here plus youâ€™d want to probably do it on something more blockchain facing to incorporate a fee structure unless a one time grant is all you and your team is looking for. (edited)

HimanshuTyagi 12/02/2022 3:16 AM
Indeed, blockchain side of stack is clear and can be presented. The model we are thinking of is to reward the challengers who help with â€œspeed testâ€ and take some gas fees, and this is implemented as a Solana contract in our prototype. We will need to have a client on the AP to receive the challenge traffic. We have implemented a WiFi AP client for OpenWRT and one for AGW.

KeithR 12/02/2022 5:28 PM
Google has practically all the data you are looking for. You can use it to build a 3D representation of nearly every building in a city. It would be quite easy to determine that I have two radios on each of 5 floors of a five-story building based on GPS and CPI-confirmed location (which is what we do with outdoor installs now; just require the exact same process for indoors). 21:39
My personal concern is around anyone gettting too in the weeds on PoC reward optimizations and losing sight of the long term data transfer and utility of the networks
21:40

21:41

gutentag

AndrewsMD 12/11/2022 10:34 PM
I can respect the need to combat gaming. I have worked to secure good set ups that would be beneficial to the network, and gaming hurts the entire network. I feel some kinda way about â€˜gamersâ€™, if that is an appropriate term to use, but not all of us lack morals. I can think of several appropriate use cases where more than 5 indoor radios are appropriate and PoC rewards should be given until the time when the network can sustain the intended use of the technology. Take a large multi floor/multi room conference center for example. 5 indoor radios are sufficient to meet this need? Take a large multi level fitness center as another example. Certainly more than 5 indoor radios are needed due to the building structure itself. But why spend the money to install 10 indoor radios now when I wonâ€™t be rewarded for 1/2 of them until 3-4 years from now when we reach neutral host ability that is attractive enough for the big 3 telcos to join in? In my opinion, there should be an exception process that could be vigorously evaluated by Nova/The Foundation. That way, network thought leaders would have confidence that if more than 5 indoor radios are needed for a location, it has been properly vetted to ensure itâ€™s an appropriate installation, it makes great sense, and it has been deemed by Nova or the Foundation to be good for the network.
22:39
An exception process could include, but not be limited to: a provided floor plan, video proof of waking into the establishment to demonstrate the location of each radio, while the reviewer is on the video chat interacting with the installer. Just a suggestion. (edited)
AndrewsMD
For example, if an indoor radio doesnâ€™t penetrate walls and ceilings very well, how could this 10 story building be optimally outfitted with only 5 indoor radios? (edited)
KeithR 12/11/2022 11:10 PM
Five indoor radios per hex should be just fine for a 10-story building. My four-story commercial building has seven full hexes on it and arguably two or three more parts of hexes. My pessimistic design is that I needed four indoor radios per floor. So that would be, in the worst case scenario, a need for 16 radios; very easily achieved with seven hexes. I would just need to put in some effort to ensure the GPS pucks are disbursed around the building's windows. A 10-story building doesn't seem that much more difficult then my scenario; though numerically, it would seem that 10-stories is the limit (seems a reasonable limit to me). What I would much prefer is that Nova/FreedomFi builds in a way for such setups to not have to use the GPS pucks. $100 to initiate the process plus $40 per radio and some level of scrutiny from the CPI seems fair. Maybe in this case, an actual CPI needs to visit the site to confirm the radios' locations. That's a lot of wiring going through random rooms to reach a window; especially since a commercial building is more likely to have a hallway running through the middle of the building.
KeithR

Recorded on 12/12/2022 0:00 HIP74 high level recap 01:41 Community Feedback on HIP74 and Subsequent Changes 03:05 Discussions and arguments on proposed rewards points for indoor radios 04:45 Updated Modeled Coverage and increased reward points for indoor radios 07:18 Highest coverage points per hex for an indoor radio adjusted to 400 points from 16 points 09:42 When to resubmit CPI approval with obstruction data oracle in mind 13:28 Mobile Explorer to go live by end of December 2022 15:10 Mobile Explorer to support 5G coverage simulation 17:28 How 5G coverage simulation works for indoor radios 19:25 The limitation of the modeled coverage model and how to improve 21:35 An upcoming HIP on mapping and how it validates modeled coverage 24:25 Verified coverage after modeled coverage 26:38 The biggest bottleneck for mapper readiness 29:00 The biggest priority for nova is to launch helium mobile 32:10 HIP74 voting to happen soon 33:39 HIP74 next steps and phases 35:35 Future HIPs for 5G: hex rating, 3rd party cellular usage data for hex usefulness, carrier input on hex weighting, mapper rewards, phone mapping rewards, etc.

Chris 12/13/2022 1:13 PM
PoC is a super powerful mechanism. It basically works for outdoor overage. It doesnâ€™t work for indoor coverage & I donâ€™t think Helium has any path in the near term for changing that (or introducing an alternative mechanism with similar power) (edited)
capcom 12/13/2022 1:18 PM
why does it not work indoors?
capcom
why does it not work indoors?
Chris 12/13/2022 1:21 PM
Outdoors, area covered is an ok proxy for a cellâ€™s utility (especially when coupled with easily accessed data about population density or coverage from MNOs). Further, you can get a relatively good sense of area covered in outdoor environments (thanks to mapping & propagation modeling)
13:26
Indoors, that all breaks down. A tiny bar basement might be hugely valuable. Propagation modeling is possible, but no longer easy or do-able with only publicly available information. Population density estimates are pretty good at resolutions like a census block, but things break down if youâ€™re looking at 500 sq ft of coverage
13:27
Mappers run into issues tooâ€” indoor locations often arenâ€™t openly accessible to everyone in the way that public roads are (edited)

5
14:46

14:48
We need to move in small incremental steps and this HIP, IMO, moves us a great deal forwardâ€¦ and also lays the foundation for how to continue improving... counting hexes we radiate into (vs you are in), using res 12 vs crazy big hexes, using various types of oracles (starting with obstruction data) are all important building blocks for us to continue iterating on going forward

hashc0de
is the fact that indoor radios continue to get a UBI a concern for you on this HIP? as you mentioned above it's the part that's not directly addressed.
Chris 12/13/2022 3:01 PM
Sort of. The initial HIP nerfed indoor hotspots. I thought that was appropriate since no one has a plan for how to reasonably incentivize good indoor deployments. Based on discussion here, it looks like that nerfing of indoor hotspots may have been accidental as much as intended. I get @zer0tweets point that progress has to happen one step at a time. My concern isn't specifically with the UBI remaining in place for indoor hotspots. Rather, I'm concerned that the UBI outlined in the HIP may be large enough that buying a bunch of indoor hotspots and throwing them in closets is the economically favored strategy for someone looking to accumulate MOBILE

hashc0de 12/13/2022 8:00 PM
life is "lumpy". i think it's reasonable to propose adding moving averages to these things.
20:01
one of the problems with our current chain is that we can't easily go past epoch boundaries with state. and even if we did, we're bound by block history on the nodes.
20:03
the new implementation uses on chain data feeds for things like dao utility score components.

@here Let's do a TEMPERATURE CHECK on this HIP! Vote with an emoji reaction below: Yes, Ready to go to a vote No, Not ready to go to a vote Yes, but have more questions.
hashc0de 12/14/2022 12:04 PM

1
Anthonyra 12/15/2022 1:33 AM
I do have a PR out for grammar and typos. But unfortunately LaTeX + tables donâ€™t play nicely on GitHub and I havenâ€™t taken the time to make screenshot images of the tables (with regards to the simplified example given) However, I think there needs to be more details about how the calculation works. I feel that the scope should be on rewarding areas and not individual hotspots to ensure coverage is rewarded over simply existing. It already tries to do this with averaging out coverage points but I think dumbing it down would go much farther. For example, what RF dBm is considered good service? Iâ€™m no expert here so I canâ€™t put a number. Then take a res 10, 9 or 8 and calculate all the res 12 hexes that meet that strength or higher. Find the % of res 12 inside the targeted hex that meets that signal strength requirement and reward that target hex accordingly. The final piece to the puzzle is to generate a noise factor (coverage difficulty) for each target hex. Based on obstruction data. The more obstructions the more noise the harder it is to fill with good coverage. (Obstructions should only account for buildings and not trees etc) Putting it all together. Hexes should be rewarded for ability to provide good coverage. The hex rewards are split based on hotspots ability to provide good res 12 hexes. Also indoor and outdoor should be separated. This bit is far more trickier but I feel like from a network build out perspective first should come outdoor and than indoor. So maybe not rewarding indoor for coverage isnâ€™t terrible? Since youâ€™re probably installing with a customer already in mind (coffee shop people) but then again with data not being metered. The return on effort is always a sensitive topic (edited)
01:35
With the above approach each target hex will have its own rewards with hotspots being rewarded in each. But hotpotâ€™s could get multiple target hex rewards depending on location installed. Since hotspots could exist in multiple target hexes providing good signal strength res 12s
01:37
It also simplifies deployment a bit since each deployment should be done to maximize the filling of empty res 12 hexes with good coverage. For maximum rewards.
Anthonyra

But unfortunately LaTeX + tables donâ€™t play nicely on GitHub and I havenâ€™t taken the time to make screenshot images of the tables (with regards to the simplified example given) However, I think there needs to be more details about how the calculation works. I feel that the scope should be on rewarding areas and not individual hotspots to ensure coverage is rewarded over simply existing. It already tries to do this with averaging out coverage points but I think dumbing it down would go much farther. For example, what RF dBm is considered good service? The_Professional 12/15/2022 7:50 AM
Forgive me as there is a bunch of points in here. Ill do my best to answer what I think I can. So there is some what an industry standard of what is good signal. Its not exactly cut and dry but for the sake of making this easy we need to set a number. See photo for example Now with that being said. There's a couple things we do need to look at. Obstruction data must include all obstructions. This signal, unless strong enough, wont make it through a car door and certainly not a tree. I know this data comes from maps so I don't think a single tree will matter but if there is a forest then it will matter. I like your multiple hex idea but I don't think people realize the true strength and distance of these radios. I think your idea could be implemented in the next version or update to this hip. This is a starting point and will give people an idea of what these radios can do. Its FAR from perfect but its something other than just UBI. Its still UBI but UBI v1.2. I can put money down that as soon as this go live there is going to be a flood of comments along the lines of... I spent 1500 dollars on a radio and I can only get down the street! My lora could ping China from Santa Monica.
1
07:50
This hip is tearing off a band aid slowly. A lot of people got into this because they heard they can just plug in a radio. I have seen some horrible outdoor installs that pointed directly into their roof or they are not high enough to clear the tallest thing in their neighborhood. Now with that being said. Nova NEEDS to clear up their intentions. This has become murky with the announcement of Helium Mobile. Is helium 5g still focused on neutral host or its own HMNO(hybrid mobile network operator)? Installing radios for neutral host is not the same as creating a network from scratch. Overlapping coverage is not what we need for neutral host. A good analogy is painting a home. The carriers radios are painters with spray guns. They can cover a wall in minutes. We are holding a brush. Do you go and paint over the spots that they just covered? Or do you think we are better suited to take the masking tape off and help touch up the spot they missed? If we are still sticking to neutral host which is what Boris mentions all the time. We need to start working on ripping this Band-Aid off. Those outdoor radios that are installed in residential or with very good overlapping coverage are almost useless. Sorry not sorry. Its as useless as stacking indoor radios inside a basement. I know I am bashing outdoors there but even indoors are not perfect. This hip like I mentioned is just UBI+. Indoor radios need validation. Either through the spot or through some form or mapping app. Indoors should be nerfed but long term they are still the play. Carriers are now spending the money to go indoors. Do what the carriers are doing. We cant compete outdoors so lets go indoors. I know this is alot and might be a very unpopular opinion to some but the truth sometimes hurts.
1
1

Forgive me as there is a bunch of points in here. Ill do my best to answer what I think I can. So there is some what an industry standard of what is good signal. Its not exactly cut and dry but for the sake of making this easy we need to set a number. See photo for example Now with that being said. There's a couple things we do need to look at. Anthonyra 12/15/2022 7:54 AM
For clarity, the signal strength calculation should include all obstructions but the target hex noise factor (coverage difficultly) is also intended as a proxy to population to determine if that hex should be saturated (downtown) or if a few should be good (farm) should only be based on buildings.
07:57
Clarity on intentions is also a valid point. I do agree that indoor is probably the most â€œdeadâ€ spots for sure. But itâ€™s hard to prime the pump when itâ€™s so easily gamed. Honestly it makes sense to me to remove PoC and simply reward generously for data. But than you need to worry about a shit ton of dummy data if you â€œrewardâ€ for data vice simply for charging for it.
Anthonyra
For clarity, the signal strength calculation should include all obstructions but the target hex noise factor (coverage difficultly) is also intended as a proxy to population to determine if that hex should be saturated (downtown) or if a few should be good (farm) should only be based on buildings.

A farm should get less rewards where a downtown with bad coverage and alot of people. A farm with no coverage and no people does not make for good coverage.

gateholder 12/15/2022 8:49 AM
ya I obviously went pretty far with when they were talking about doing there own coverage and then also being neutral host. but I can also say I cover the insides of buildings better than I expect now its not great service but its good enough to get 10mbps in side and where my native tmobile was spotty, I want them to launch there whole network, I think that is the real long term play, but you can't start there. I do agree filling in dead zones could be very profitable but I don't see a problem with covering the same area with more bandwith I noticed at a couple of my installs that when we would stop and eat or be waiting and be on our phone I for example have tmobile where my other installer had boost, and I would be sitting there streaming video etc. and his phone would hicup with data because if you are in a "overcrowded" place and your on sec carrier they prioritize there own, we all know this happens at sporting events and parades, etc.
xodpox 12/15/2022 11:24 AM
clarity is going to help HNT and bring more orders (I know I am sitting on close to $100K in equipment orders, waiting for clarity, and willing to hold until that is achieved or prices go down more).
HimanshuTyagi 12/15/2022 6:40 PM
Coverage planning and deployment is complex activity for carriers. All said and done, decentralized deployments cannot simply circumvent it. It can only find alternative, decentralized methods for it. Carriers start by simulators/emulator to plan the location and then do physical drive tests to check the coverage. At the same time, there is a lot of automation and visibility software to assist with tracking antenna tilt etc. All these things are done by multiple vendors with various products. It is unfair to expect PoC to do all of this. It best replaces the simulation for coverage planning part, and even there it needs to keep evolving.
18:42
The idea above of a separate subDAO for all these functionalities can help here. It will allow creation of a transparent ecosystem for â€œvendorsâ€ to evolve to help with different types of PoC and deployment software. Some people here have expressed interest in this direction â€” we will try to put up a HIP along this lines (and wait to be slaughtered :D)
HimanshuTyagi
The idea above of a separate subDAO for all these functionalities can help here. It will allow creation of a transparent ecosystem for â€œvendorsâ€ to evolve to help with different types of PoC and deployment software. Some people here have expressed interest in this direction â€” we will try to put up a HIP along this lines (and wait to be slaughtered :D)
gutentag 12/15/2022 6:46 PM
Can you explain more your thought process on why additional subDAOs would be needed for this? If the efforts are toward the Mobile subDAO, what is benefits do you have in mind as a result of putting them into a separate silo?
HimanshuTyagi 12/15/2022 6:50 PM
Itâ€™s just a thought right now, will work to articulate it over the next week. But they be basic idea is that we canâ€™t trust reliable measurements by individuals and they can game it. We should allow larger groups, even vendors, to come together and build reputation. So tomorrow if T Mobile wants to provide a proof of coverage using its subscribers locations, we can include that as well. But it may be better if I put all this in a draft first â€¦ bite sized thoughts can confuse
1
18:51
Basically we need a place to allow many solutions to evolve and build reputation. The basic Helium PoC here is fine and cannot be expected to be perfect in one shot
gutentag

HimanshuTyagi 12/15/2022 6:57 PM
Also, to your point of Mobile subDAO, the PoC here can remain and this extra subDAO can supplement it by offering data from other sources.
gutentag 12/15/2022 7:03 PM

greenz 12/15/2022 8:33 PM
So does the 5 per hex overlap count towards indoor and outdoor or are they exclusive? Can I have 5 indoor and 5 outdoor in the same location without any reduction or penalty?
gutentag 12/15/2022 8:56 PM

20:57

zer0tweets 12/15/2022 9:01 PM
â€¦catching up on the back scroll..
21:02
1/ @Anthonyra point about counting 1 tree vs. many trees vs. building etc. - obstruction data oracle will take care of it. It will rely on the same data that carriers (or services like Google Planner) use to estimate signal propagation, taking into account topographic data as well as clutter data in the area
21:02
2/ @Anthonyra point about â€œrewarding areasâ€ - I agree not all areas should be rewarded equally and we will propose a separate evolutionary HIP (or maybe several) to tackle that as well. The point of current HIP is to start rewarding for coverage vs. for radios just existing and laying down the framework that can be further evolved down with zoning data, carrier input etc
21:04
3/ @The_Professional HMNO vs neutral host. We are building neutral host network. But how you build neutral host is a function of who is going to use it. I think HMNO is the near term, low hanging fruit use case for the neutral host network we are building. From Helium Mobile standpoint (as well as most MVNOs like xFi, Charter, Dish) we want to not use MNO network in as many locations with slow moving crows as possible (because this will make our bill smaller). You are right that from top 3 MNO standpoint, they only care about very few locations (mostly indoor). Because of this, there needs to be operator input into it and the ability for operators to incentivize deployments in certain hexes over others (maybe invoking some MOBILE stake/burn mechanism). That, again, though is another HIP and another source of external data (aka oracle) that HIP 74 lays the foundation for. (edited)
1
1
greenz
So does the 5 per hex overlap count towards indoor and outdoor or are they exclusive? Can I have 5 indoor and 5 outdoor in the same location without any reduction or penalty?

So does the 5 per hex overlap count towards indoor and outdoor or are they exclusive? Can I have 5 indoor and 5 outdoor in the same location without any reduction or penalty?
HimanshuTyagi 12/16/2022 2:43 AM
I think the idea is to avoid overlapping coverage. It is inefficient and will also introduce interference. So by this logic, indoor and outdoor both should count in the limit of 5.
1
zer0tweets
3/ @The_Professional HMNO vs neutral host. We are building neutral host network. But how you build neutral host is a function of who is going to use it. I think HMNO is the near term, low hanging fruit use case for the neutral host network we are building. From Helium Mobile standpoint (as well as most MVNOs like xFi, Charter, Dish) we want to not use MNO network in as many locations with slow moving crows as possible (because this will make our bill smaller). You are right that from top 3 MNO standpoint, they only care about very few locations (mostly indoor). Because of this, there needs to be operator input into it and the ability for operators to incentivize deployments in certain hexes over others (maybe invoking some MOBILE stake/burn mechanism). That, again, though is another HIP and another source of external data (aka oracle) that HIP 74 lays the foundation for. (edited)

zer0tweets 12/16/2022 9:12 AM
Current thinking is indoor / outdoor overlap for a max total of 5 for indoor + outdoor. Although in reality that won't happen often, because for outdoors, obstruction data oracle treats most indoors as "no signal" inside

meowshka 12/16/2022 11:28 AM
@5G Owner We've updated the HIP74 with the following sections: - Rationale and Alternatives - Deployment Impact - Unresolved Questions - Success Metrics Additionally, it includes changes to the proposed Indoor Radio rewards that will approximately keep the Genesis-period reward ratio between Indoor and Outdoor Radios in place. We appreciate everyone's input and feedback! https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0074-mobile-poc-modeled-coverage-rewards.md

Chris
What's the point of rewarding 5 radios covering the same hex?
zer0tweets 12/16/2022 2:08 PM
I think some level of redundancy is warranted. We proposed 5, because any more and itâ€™s actually creating harmful interference since there may not be enough channels in the band for SAS to separate the radios. It might make sense to re-evaluate down the line to promote further de-clusterization and check if 5 is really providing redundancy i.e. if itâ€™s really separate backhaul, connected to separate gateways etc. - but I maybe follow on iterations.
Hans
How is indoor CBRS better than Wifi6E from a protocol perspective? Long term wouldn't this be better for indoors?
zer0tweets 12/16/2022 2:09 PM
It makes sense to incentivize indoor hexes more vs. outdoor, because while there is less of those hexes, that coverage tends to be more valuable (people spend more time indoors, macro cells donâ€™t penetrate walls etc.). â€œWi-Fi vs. CBRSâ€ is a separate topic from â€œindoor vs. outdoorâ€ IMO. Wi-Fi definitely has a lot going for it, particularly indoors.
4
gateholder
I do have 1 critique when it comes to indoor I understand rewarding more for a hex but why not reward the max value for the hex and all adjacent squares but so (540 80 per hex) that makes most sense to me. Maybe a another radius of max value (16) if we are trying to value adjust thoughts?
zer0tweets 12/16/2022 2:11 PM
Would like to better understand how is this proposal different from what's currently in the HIP. The reason why we are still counting hexes and approximating coverage for indoors is because, philosophically, we want to move away from "points for radios" and towards "points for hexes covered." Down the line I think there are options to find indoor clutter data sources and start incorporating them.
gutentag
with this fist pass at propogation, yes

Here's my scenario. I have 4 outdoor radios on a roof and 1 indoor unit. The GPS puck is located almost directly below the outdoor radios, so I'm expecting the same hex. Will potential rewards be lost because of the common hex all 5 radios share as well as the indoor adjacent hexes overlapping with the 4 outdoor radios? Asking because I'll find another location for the indoor if rewards will be lost with this configuration

gateholder 12/16/2022 3:11 PM
I guess my goal was to make sure there getting rewarded properly arguably there is no benefit to having 5 indoors in the same hex even facing different directions I still get reception directly behind the indoor directional unit and 2 walls almost 100 ft away (100ish rsr). I thought you would want to get those 20 units out of the basement make them show it is in a useful place and I would think at most 2 indoors per hex is probably the best realistic middle ground. but I know this doesn't apply to tall building and buildings with say concrete walls I get there is nuance but I would rather air on the side of usefulness rather than trying to accommodate the exception that will likely be abused, I would say we need to open a special CPI option for indoors of multi story office buildings other wise no more than 2 indoors to a hex and they need to be at least 4 hexes away to get max rewards for each set.

Hans 12/17/2022 12:55 PM
Imagine RF signals as a conversation between people. These people are in a room with hundreds of other people. If other people in the crowd are talking too loud you cant hear the conversation with your partner. So in order to create order the owner creates rules for how loud people can talk so that everyone can hear the conversations with their partner. That's why EIRP regulations exist.
Hans
So Elmo, you're saying the value with CBRS is private network offloading? Can you give me an example of a perfect deployment location in your view?

a variation in the delay of received packets... aka jitter For calls to work on a network latency must be 150ms one way. 300 both ways but max jitter should be 50ms. (edited)

jhella 12/20/2022 11:01 AM
Also adding my concern over the indoor rewards (as proposed). As someone who does enterprise deployments, this rewards mechanism will not encourage us to place our indoor units in high value foot traffic locations. Way less effort to leave them in their current state for the reasons described by others. If the plan is to tweak PoC over time through multiple HIPs then why not wait and err on the side of less rewards until it's better understood when/where to place indoor units? Otherwise, the network is unnecessarily diluting it's circulating token supply to have indoor units stacked in homes / closets.
1

The_Professional 12/20/2022 1:02 PM
That's exactly what they were doing. They were literally rebuilding inside of warehouses to the t. They were installing radios inside running all the cabling and they were able to build a BOM within unreal. They literally just printed out the models for the cabinets all the runs every single radio mount and where they should all go. It's expensive but when you have a large job It pays itself back. Especially when it's some big company that can't shut down the plant for more than a couple days. When you have a game plan written out to the t it's going to save you more than the $40,000 in labor.

waveform 12/21/2022 3:23 PM
I've understood it as a completed HIP has code and a passing vote. It needs both to be complete. A passing vote does not make it a complete HIP. Neither does completed code make it a complete HIP. One can come before the other as it needs both.
waveform

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped

Another_AKA 12/21/2022 7:59 PM
I recognize that what can become a HIP is sometimes a moving target. I've always been a bit concerned about the thinking about a HIP must come with code because who wants to do all the development for something that may not pass. In my mind, HIP 70 basically sets the bar that a HIP just needs a group willing to do the code to be brought up for vote. It would be silly to do all the Solana code work only to have a failing HIP.
valerie
waiting for authors to chime in. dont want to speak for them @zer0tweets
zer0tweets 12/21/2022 8:47 PM
The vote was paused because there was some confusion as to whether this HIP is â€œreplacing genesis.â€ This HIP does not deal with genesis vs. programmatic treasury minting and does not affect the total number of tokens going to hotspot operators. It assumes that there is some X number of total tokens to be attributed to the hotspot operator pool and focuses, exclusively, on the algorithm for distributing this X amount between individual hotspotsâ€¦ moving the algorithm from UBI to looking at coverage in res 12 hexes. Weâ€™ll be amending a few sections where we used words â€œreplaces genesisâ€ and hope for the foundation to initiate voting process next week.
Another_AKA
I recognize that what can become a HIP is sometimes a moving target. I've always been a bit concerned about the thinking about a HIP must come with code because who wants to do all the development for something that may not pass. In my mind, HIP 70 basically sets the bar that a HIP just needs a group willing to do the code to be brought up for vote. It would be silly to do all the Solana code work only to have a failing HIP.
zer0tweets 12/21/2022 8:50 PM
I've heard the sentiment about "code must be ready for HIP vote to pass" but, frankly don't get it either... nobody wants to code anything until there some confidence that it's not throw away work... not that it applies to HIP 74, because the coding part there is largely ready; we'll be showing off 5G explorer any day now so folks get a glimpse of their modeled coverage

20:57

20:58

Submorf 01/05/2023 11:01 AM
How is the new coverage map hexes determining signal strength. Is it just theoretical based on placement and radio type?
Submorf
How is the new coverage map hexes determining signal strength. Is it just theoretical based on placement and radio type?
gutentag 01/05/2023 11:59 AM
it uses a propogation model to estimate the coverage of a Small Cell Radio based on location, orientation and height reported during registration and the Radio GPS

Hans 01/07/2023 10:31 AM
Before this hip is passed the rewards between the indoor hotspots and outdoor hotspots should be checked to be balanced fairly. Right now it seems like indoors are getting rewarded for just participating - whereas outdoors have to be installed high on masts and providing acres of coverage for similar rewards. The average outdoor earnings should be 2.5x more than the indoor hotspot. (edited)
2
1
Hans
Before this hip is passed the rewards between the indoor hotspots and outdoor hotspots should be checked to be balanced fairly. Right now it seems like indoors are getting rewarded for just participating - whereas outdoors have to be installed high on masts and providing acres of coverage for similar rewards. The average outdoor earnings should be 2.5x more than the indoor hotspot. (edited)
KeithR 01/07/2023 12:04 PM
If the rule of thumb is that 80% of traffic will be seen indoors is correct, shouldn't indoors be encouraged and rewarded more than outdoor? I think you are also neglecting the difficulty of having to wire a GPS puck out to a window from the center of a commercial building and have that cable be unseen or at least discreetly placed. Outdoor installs allow for so much greater vulgarity. (edited)
1
KeithR
If the rule of thumb is that 80% of traffic will be seen indoors is correct, shouldn't indoors be encouraged and rewarded more than outdoor? I think you are also neglecting the difficulty of having to wire a GPS puck out to a window from the center of a commercial building and have that cable be unseen or at least discreetly placed. Outdoor installs allow for so much greater vulgarity. (edited)
Hans 01/07/2023 12:31 PM
It depends on what Helium wants to incentivize? Are we trying to provide as much coverage as possible to as much geography as possible in high demand areas? Or are we trying to bring CBRS spectrum to indoor locations? Is CBRS best used indoors when WiFi offloading is just around the corner? Do indoor radios offer better coverage than outdoor radios? We really haven't gotten a lot of clarity from Helium in what their design intent is - everything seems so muddy. On one hand they're clearly favoring geography with the new console simulations, but now it seems like they're incentivizing indoor hotspots simply for participating at rates much higher than outdoor hotspots.
12:34
We don't even know how many points the avg outdoor hotspot gets. Some of us have laboriously counted a few outdoor hotspots and are not in agreeance on a average.
12:38
It seems like a fair way to do it is that we need to take the avg (or median) outdoor hotspot's coverage points and peg it's rewards at a multiple that the indoor hotspot gets for participating - and that multiple should numerically represent how much the network favors indoor coverage. During Genesis that was 2.5x greater than a indoor, but this could change. (edited)
KeithR
If the rule of thumb is that 80% of traffic will be seen indoors is correct, shouldn't indoors be encouraged and rewarded more than outdoor? I think you are also neglecting the difficulty of having to wire a GPS puck out to a window from the center of a commercial building and have that cable be unseen or at least discreetly placed. Outdoor installs allow for so much greater vulgarity. (edited)

KeithR 01/07/2023 3:28 PM

Using "likelihood of slow moving people (aka users)" as the intention of the incentive means that Grand Central Station is the ideal location. Though from a raw business perspective for Helium Mobile, the real intention of any incentive will likely be to "get off t.mobile's network as often as possible". (edited)

ghiijsnb 01/09/2023 6:52 PM
The simulated obstacle data mentioned in hip74, my understanding is that the simulation is always just a simulation, and there will be deviations from the actual situation. Using the simulated data to determine the actual income will cause many wrong judgments, such as signal strength , whether there are real obstacles in the orientation, etc.
1
ghiijsnb
The simulated obstacle data mentioned in hip74, my understanding is that the simulation is always just a simulation, and there will be deviations from the actual situation. Using the simulated data to determine the actual income will cause many wrong judgments, such as signal strength , whether there are real obstacles in the orientation, etc.

Brainstormer 01/10/2023 12:14 AM
because poor coverage will likely be found indoors. signal coming in from cell tower will be attenuated when it goes indoors. if there is a radio indoor, your radio, even at it's low power, could be stronger than the carrier's cell towers.
00:15
outdoors you're competing against the signal of the cell tower, which is a lot stronger and most places have good coverage.

Hans 01/10/2023 10:45 AM
Capcom talked a bit about how he envisions the network - CBRS is one small piece. He had concerns about the signal propagation and high costs of hardware. He seemed to like WiFi due to its low cost and less complexity. These statements echo my concerns with HIP-74. Are we aligning the PoC to track with what we want CBRS to do? Wi-Fi is a better alternative to CBRS indoors and yet we are incentivizing it at higher rates than outdoors.
10:47
CBRS has its place. I do not think it works well in indoor locations because it requires SAS and clear LOS with GPS satellites. CBRS does work well in congested environments outdoors like downtowns and public parks due to it having less interference.
Hans 01/10/2023 10:55 AM

capcom 01/10/2023 12:23 PM
i don't think there's a "best", just different situations requiring different solutions. the range of CRBS should be quite a lot better than wifi and the spectrum is less congested. but then again, it is more expensive. so in a situation where you need to cover a large indoor area for example but can only physically situate a single hotspot, CBRS might be the better solution. if access to space and backhaul isn't an issue, several wifi hotspots might work

14:33
https://www.lightreading.com/cable-tech/a-closer-look-at-how-cable-can-profit-in-mobile/d/d-id/782545
A closer look at how cable can profit in mobile | Light Reading
New Street Research analysts estimated that Charter's mobile customers generated earnings of just $3 per customer. However, they explained how that figure can be manipulated by strategies like offloading.
Chris 01/10/2023 2:35 PM

gateholder 01/10/2023 3:18 PM
We are in the right place the only question is are we going to finish in gold silver or brozne...
1
Chris
Something isn't squaring for me with how this is getting talked about...why don't we see passpoint in use more often now if its value proposition is so straightforward? (edited)
capcom 01/10/2023 3:19 PM
the other consideration is that the economics of deploying wifi hotspots in high foot traffic areas in a traditional way are also not great. imagine a telco trying to get wifi hotspots inside retail stores, etc. the hardware is not really the issue, it's more of a real estate/backhaul problem. and then for those retailers/etc who do have passpoint enabled devices, there isn't a simple aggregator that they can go to in order to make it easy. they aren't going to go negotiate an offload deal with the 3 MNO's themselves. that's what Orion has been trying to solve, but they also have the two sided marketplace problem that helium solves well on the supply side
capcom
the other consideration is that the economics of deploying wifi hotspots in high foot traffic areas in a traditional way are also not great. imagine a telco trying to get wifi hotspots inside retail stores, etc. the hardware is not really the issue, it's more of a real estate/backhaul problem. and then for those retailers/etc who do have passpoint enabled devices, there isn't a simple aggregator that they can go to in order to make it easy. they aren't going to go negotiate an offload deal with the 3 MNO's themselves. that's what Orion has been trying to solve, but they also have the two sided marketplace problem that helium solves well on the supply side
gateholder 01/10/2023 3:23 PM
Right, there is a rather large slice of the pie in this. But no one has figured out a Successful monetization of it... really the best positioned in this is the cox, comcast, spectrum etc because they could easily give a credit for services rendered (edited)
capcom
the other consideration is that the economics of deploying wifi hotspots in high foot traffic areas in a traditional way are also not great. imagine a telco trying to get wifi hotspots inside retail stores, etc. the hardware is not really the issue, it's more of a real estate/backhaul problem. and then for those retailers/etc who do have passpoint enabled devices, there isn't a simple aggregator that they can go to in order to make it easy. they aren't going to go negotiate an offload deal with the 3 MNO's themselves. that's what Orion has been trying to solve, but they also have the two sided marketplace problem that helium solves well on the supply side
Hans 01/10/2023 3:24 PM
Open source your firmware to allow outside vendors (like OpenDDwrt, Linksys, Netgear, pfsense) to incorporate it into their hardware. This would vastly increase Helium's footprint, driving adoption and usage
gateholder
Right, there is a rather large slice of the pie in this. But no one has figured out a Successful monetization of it... really the best positioned in this is the cox, comcast, spectrum etc because they could easily give a credit for services rendered (edited)
capcom 01/10/2023 3:25 PM
IMO the tit for tat model is not really a good enough incentive. we have seen many entities try to pull that off over the years. again, IMO, people want to participate in the upside when the network succeeds. it's kind of like backing Oculus in the kickstarter. you get a $1000 headset, they get a $3bn exit to Facebook. doesn't really seem fair
Hans
Open source your firmware to allow outside vendors (like OpenDDwrt, Linksys, Netgear, pfsense) to incorporate it into their hardware. This would vastly increase Helium's footprint, driving adoption and usage
capcom 01/10/2023 3:25 PM
for sure. the only really unique part of the hardware we have built is secureboot for the firmware, and hardware key storage for the blockchain keys. the rest is very standard enterprise wifi ap equipment
1
Hans 01/10/2023 3:27 PM

Another_AKA 01/11/2023 3:44 PM
I'll open a hornets nest...should the foundation be able to make tweaks to mobile POC without a HIP every time? Do we need a HIP to promote POC changes that the network needs (e.g. new offloader wants more installs here, or this type of install, etc). I can see good and bad here. Speed of change -> good. Tyranny -> bad
Carl-bot BOT 01/11/2023 3:44 PM
Modelled coverage is the first step in incentivizing useful coverage instead of reward radios just for being online and having a good connection. Upcoming proposals will include using publicly available datasets like population density and zoning to identify useful hexes and incentivize radio deployments.
Another_AKA 01/11/2023 3:47 PM

gutentag 01/11/2023 3:54 PM
to slightly modify your question though: Should HIPs be required for every tweak to MOBILE PoC? I would say that itself, ought to be addressed as part of a HIP. In my personal ideal world, a HIP feels necessary for larger changes (like HIP-74), but if we find quickly that an unforeseen consequence is harming the Network which can be fixed with a small adjustment, we should prioritize solutions and speed. new stuff = HIP, adjustments to existing stuff =? HIP
Carl-bot BOT 01/11/2023 3:54 PM
Modelled coverage is the first step in incentivizing useful coverage instead of reward radios just for being online and having a good connection. Upcoming proposals will include using publicly available datasets like population density and zoning to identify useful hexes and incentivize radio deployments.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 01/13/2023 5:55 PM
Ok so if say there are 10 radios covering a hex, only the top 5 strongest signals would be paid POC?
mcharliem 01/13/2023 5:55 PM
Thatâ€™s my understanding.
17:56
First to install would be tie breaker if there were two (or more) tied for fifth strongest.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 01/13/2023 5:59 PM
ok re-reading this bit:
For each hex, get at most 5 Outdoor Radios with the top signal strength of the same level. If there are more than 5 Radios with the same signal strength level, use the coverage_claim_time value to determine the top 5 oldest installations where coverage_claim_time is the timestamp when the Radio received the spectrum access grant for the first time. To prevent rewarding "dead" Radios, we propose to reset coverage_claim_time if the Radio was not generating a Heartbeat for more than 72 hours and use the time of the last Heartbeat as the new coverage_claim_time.
18:00
Ok, objection withdrawn. @gutentag
1
18:00
I misread it as an absolute, not a tiebreaker.

gateholder 01/13/2023 6:13 PM
I came to the conclusion that we prob shouldn't have more than 4 radios long term and to some degree they shouldn't be in the same rez 12 hex
burkano 01/13/2023 9:11 PM
So more than 5 radios can be covering the same hex if the signal strength is different?
burkano
So more than 5 radios can be covering the same hex if the signal strength is different?
gutentag 01/13/2023 9:36 PM
can: yes, but will be rewarded: no. only the 5 strongest signals in each target hex are counted as coverage points (edited)
burkano 01/13/2023 9:36 PM
I see
21:37
Do the radios get their location based on the address submitted or the latitude and longitude that is automatically detected and inputted in CPI registration?
gutentag 01/13/2023 10:50 PM
radios get their location from the GPS in the radio itself, the address is used during CPI registration. The Helium Explorer 5G layer and the Modelled Coverage Explorer both use data from the SAS, which uses the GPS from the radio. Keep in mind, if the radio GPS coordinates drift too far from the CPI registered coordinates, the SAS will deny the radio and kick it off air (edited)
gutentag
radios get their location from the GPS in the radio itself, the address is used during CPI registration. The Helium Explorer 5G layer and the Modelled Coverage Explorer both use data from the SAS, which uses the GPS from the radio. Keep in mind, if the radio GPS coordinates drift too far from the CPI registered coordinates, the SAS will deny the radio and kick it off air (edited)

JD - HeliumDeploy 01/17/2023 7:40 AM
so if someone was to aim a 430h into the sky a bit, with no obstructions. In theory that radio should earn tons of coverage points no? Would cpi even approve something like this? Are there limits to the maximum angles? (edited)
hersh
Now that hip 74 is passed. when will it be implemented?
valerie 01/17/2023 7:59 AM
likely over the next month but authors can give a better timeline.
eMcSteez603ðŸ¥ 01/17/2023 11:11 AM
Is this just for the 5g miners?
JD - HeliumDeploy
so if someone was to aim a 430h into the sky a bit, with no obstructions. In theory that radio should earn tons of coverage points no? Would cpi even approve something like this? Are there limits to the maximum angles? (edited)
gutentag 01/17/2023 11:14 AM
theory yes, in practice no. that is accounted for in the propogation model tools. if you aim too far up you "give up" nearby coverage and the model caps distances at a certain point. it is best practice to orient the radios to provide as much coverage at ground (where people and phones are) level
1
11:15
a mental model that has helped me is thinking of trying to water your yard with a garden hose. If you aim too low you lose range, and if you aim too high the ground below you doesn't get watered, and the hose only sprays so far, there is a happy medium in there somewhere ha (edited)
JD - HeliumDeploy 01/17/2023 11:18 AM
ok thanks makes sense
Zbb 01/17/2023 1:08 PM
anyone know if the map was updated yesterday? still not showing despite being online and earning rewards
meowshka 01/17/2023 4:41 PM
@ElonTusk | 5Gchipped getting back to you on the distance limit. We set the radius limit to 1000m. We looked at how far a signal usable for subscribers goes in a sample set of Radios and doubled that distance. A larger radius would also be too heavy for the computation, so it's a tradeoff. This is something that will eventually be specified in the dev docs.
1

The FreedomFi Gateway is a multi-protocol miner for the Helium network. It comes with the ability to mine HNT for providing LoRa coverage, and is also expandable with plug-and-play support for Powered by FreedomFi certified Helium 5G  CBRS Small Cells to mine MOBILE for providing cellular coverage and data forâ€¦

beast0n 01/18/2023 9:54 AM
Whatâ€™s the easiest way to figure out what my mobile rewards will be?
09:54
For reference, Genuine Juniper Otter is my outdoor radio.
09:55
beast0n
Whatâ€™s the easiest way to figure out what my mobile rewards will be?
gutentag 01/18/2023 10:42 AM
click on any of those hexagons and divide the "Total Radio Points" by "Total Network Points" then multiply by 100million 2244/16326964*100000000 = 13,744.13516193 in your case REMEMBER THIS IS A ROUGH ESTIMATE and assumes you have heartbeats, backhaul and all that other stuff
1
gutentag
click on any of those hexagons and divide the "Total Radio Points" by "Total Network Points" then multiply by 100million 2244/16326964*100000000 = 13,744.13516193 in your case REMEMBER THIS IS A ROUGH ESTIMATE and assumes you have heartbeats, backhaul and all that other stuff

meowshka 01/19/2023 8:20 AM
"HIP-74 proposes to limit the five oldest Radio deployments with the highest signal strength in a given hex for reward eligibility" https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0074-mobile-poc-modeled-coverage-rewards.md#impact-on-rewards
Zbb 01/19/2023 8:21 AM
